evidence_span: Irradiation Effects on Precipitates—In RX Zy-4F, the two intermetallics that were present prior to irradiation (mainly Zr(Fe,Cr)2, and Zr2(Fe,Ni) to a much lesser extent) can still be detected after irradiation at 400°C (Fig. 3).

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk3

evidence_span: Whereas before irradiation (Fig. 5a), the iron/chromium (Fe/Cr) ratio remains constant and close to 2 throughout the particles, after irradiation (Fig. 5b), it drops continuously from the center to the periphery of precipitates and reaches a value of 1 at interface with the matrix.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: Low Temperatures $( \boldsymbol { \mathrm { T } } \approx 8 0 ^ { \circ } \boldsymbol { C } )$ -Both ${ \bf Z } { \bf r } _ { 2 } ( { \bf N } { \bf i } , { \bf F e } )$ and ${ \bf Z r } ( { \bf F e } , { \bf C r } ) _ { 2 }$ that are the predominant second phases in Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, respectively, undergo a rapid and complete crystalline-to-amorphous transformation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: Low Temperatures $( \boldsymbol { \mathrm { T } } \approx 8 0 ^ { \circ } \boldsymbol { C } )$ -Both ${ \bf Z } { \bf r } _ { 2 } ( { \bf N } { \bf i } , { \bf F e } )$ and ${ \bf Z r } ( { \bf F e } , { \bf C r } ) _ { 2 }$ that are the predominant second phases in Zircaloy-2 and Zircaloy-4, respectively, undergo a rapid and complete crystalline-to-amorphous transformation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: At Intermediate Temperatures $( \mathsf { T } \approx 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } C )$ The $\mathbf { Z } _ { \mathbf { I } _ { 2 } } ( \mathbf { N i } , \mathbf { F e } )$ particles remain crystalline, while the ${ \bf Z r } ( { \bf F e , C r } ) _ { 2 }$ particles undergo a partial amorphous transformation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: At Intermediate Temperatures $( \mathsf { T } \approx 3 0 0 ^ { \circ } C )$ The $\mathbf { Z } _ { \mathbf { I } _ { 2 } } ( \mathbf { N i } , \mathbf { F e } )$ particles remain crystalline, while the ${ \bf Z r } ( { \bf F e , C r } ) _ { 2 }$ particles undergo a partial amorphous transformation.

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: In the current work, this scenario was clearly encountered for the RX Zy-4 guide tube specimen irradiated at about $3 2 0 \%$ in a PWR. The partial amorphous transformation of $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathbf { F e } , \mathbf { C r } ) _ { 2 }$ phases was effectively observed

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: By contrast, the structure of $\mathbf { Z } \mathbf { r } _ { 2 } ( \mathbf { F e } , \mathbf { N i } )$ particles (similar to those observed in Zircaloy-2 but having a much lower nickel content) remained fully crystalline

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: A rather similar situation was observed for SR Zy-4 specimens taken from the lower part $( T = 3 3 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C } )$ of a cladding irradiated in PWR. However, the $Z \mathrm { r } ( \mathrm { F e } , { \cal C } _ { \mathrm { r } } ) _ { 2 }$ particles were found fully amorphous

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: a post-irradiation annealing at $6 0 0 ^ { \circ } \mathbf { C }$ revealed, or induced, an intense precipitation of tiny zirconium-iron-chromium particles (with a $\mathbf { F e / C r }$ ratio close to 2)

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: confirmed that most of $Z \mathbf { r } ( \mathbf { F e } , \mathbf { C r } ) _ { 2 }$ phases experienced a complete dissolution in SR samples

source_id: STP1245-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_10th Volume_031_chunk6
evidence_span: At High Irradiation Temperatures $( \mathsf { T } > 3 7 0 ^ { \circ } C )$ —Amorphization was not detected, but dissolution of $\mathbf { Z r } _ { 2 } ( \mathbf { F e } , \mathbf { N i } )$ and ${ \bf Z r ( F e , C r ) } _ { 2 }$ particles, solute redistribution, and secondary phase formation throughout the matrix and at grain boundaries were observed
